reviewText:
A New Beginning tries to share a positive message about climate change, our future, and our resistance to change, but the execution leaves a lot to be desired. The game is not terrible: it has its good points, and if you've ever wanted to play a dimwitted token female with a seemingly quite severe case of scoliosis who wears a sweater that covers only her boobs, then this definitely is your game.

Pros:
+Good message
+The art is quite nice
+The ruined future setting that occurs near the start of the game is very compelling
+The support team answered my emails quickly and were very helpful when I encountered a game-breaking bug

Cons:
-The English voice acting is atrocious. If you want to play the game, set the sound the German with English subtitles - the German voice acting isn't too bad.
-The English translation is not very good. There are a lot of grammatical errors and problems with colloquialisms that really should have been caught by a native English speaking proofreader before the game was published.
-There are a lot of bugs. Mainly I encountered translation bugs: various items popping up in Russian or Spanish. I also found a game-breaking bug, however, which required a replacement save file from the support team to get past.
-Everyone moves so slowly that I found myself screaming at the monitor a few times. Quickly, we must hit that switch before the facility explodes! Now, let me just take a leisurely stroll across the room. Wouldn't want to work up a sweat.
-The game is extremely resource-heavy, and I can't figure out why. My computer heats up while running this game as much as it does while playing a modern shooter.
-Many of the puzzles are absurd. Several of them require knowledge that the average person just wouldn't have. I needed a walkthrough to get through most of it, and many times I realized I would never in a million years have thought to try the thing that ended up being necessary. There's also a fair amount of pixel-hunting for tiny items that blend in.
-Between the slow movement speed of the characters and the seemingly never-ending cutscenes and dialog, by the time I was 1/3 of the way through the game I just wanted it to end.
-The ending isn't nearly as clever as it's trying to be, and felt rather anti-climactic after all those hours of listening to people talk and watching them crawl across the screen to the sound of suspenseful music.

If you can get the game cheap, enjoy ridiculous puzzles, and have a lot of patience for slow movement and long cutscenes, then feel free to give this one a try. If you're used a faster pace or just want something you feel you can solve without a walkthrough, I'd pass this one over.

reviewText:
A New Beginning - Final Cut is a point and click adventure game that contains a strong graphic novel aesthetic to all its cutscenes, but it’s the beautifully rendered 2D artwork that brings the world to life.
Daedalic’s previous releases such as Deponia and Edna & Harvey had a similar aspect but overemphasized color and cartoony humor. The tone here is much darker as it complements the rather dire storyline.

The backdrops are beautiful and the character models have a much more realistic style to them than we’ve come to expect from the developer. The mixture of early 80s haircuts and futuristic technology somehow goes well together.
It also helps the aesthetic that the music in this game is perfect with a sensational orchestrated soundtrack that goes beyond expectations.

While it can be a bit preachy about using up all natural resources, melting the polar icecaps, and destroying Earth through human ignorance and greed, you feel a bond between characters, and even the world, that a lot of games fail to establish.

The characters evolve through the story, properly accepting their roles and feelings towards certain situations.

It's not often that I consider a game hard to put down, but I found myself getting deeply invested in the plot as it unravelled thanks to its convincing characterisation and an increasingly gripping storyline. Although there's an obvious environmental focus, there's also a strong heart to the story and it's this that powers your desire to play on.

The puzzles are solid as I have found myself stumped on several for near half an hour.

In short, I highly recommend this game to those who enjoy point and click games. Be sure to check out the Deponia trilogy if you have not already.

reviewText: So, i read the reviews on here. Everyone is going on about bad voice acting. Blah, blah. Really ? Ok, so let me help you if you are interested in this. Buy it. Play and finish it. This game is worth your money and your time. That is the bottom line. It was a really great thought provoking graphic novel. And it will stick in my head for a long time to come. The puzzles are good, i could solve some of them quite easy. They are challenging, but not impossible at all. This game has a lot of emotion in it, It made me think back to old adventure games in the 80s. It has some great level design and locations.I love the art style and the color palette because it fits the game perfectly, creating the right mood. Helping to create a world that pulls you in and keeps you there. Everything compliments each other well, and creates the Ambience tied together with a great musical score. I really would like a sequel to the game, and would buy it for sure.

reviewText: A New Beginning is a point and click adventure game, by the German based developer Daedalic Entertainment. Hence, the English dub of the game leaves a lot to be asked for. Many of the intonations are painfully out of place, though the voices do match the characters to some degree. The German version suffers from none of these issues and is quite nicely voiced. If you're able to, I'd recomend playing that version. The game itself is your standard adventure, not really genre defining or groundbreaking, but the puzzles are well designed and have a good flow to them. There is relatively little scrounging around for items, and although you may be stumped from time to time, you probably won't require a guide to help you through. The visuals are also quite nice, the game has a comic book aesthetic which is a good match. The game's biggest failing probably lies in its heavy handed plot which is constantly trying to shove the dangers of global warming and nuclear down your throat. Though the writing is at times quite clever most of the time the game sounds like that environmental science class you had to sit through in 7th grade. The story is generally pretty sound, but starts to fizzle out at the end. Overall it's a well-crafted game with a plot that doesn't live up to the polish of the rest. I recomend it if you're a fan of adventure games, but if you aren't you're not missing out on much.

reviewText:
Short version: 73%‘Terminator’ meets ‘Captain Planet’ in this point ‘n’ click adventure that may be more preachy in its message than it was supposed to be, but it still tells an interesting story with simple, yet entertaining puzzle mechanics.

Long version:It is difficult to write something about saving our planet from pollution without resorting to tired speeches, but ‘A New Beginning’ almost managed to do that. Almost. While it is not just some pro-environmentalist propaganda, and the theme is integrated well into the story, sometimes the message it tries to convey is little more than a PSA after a Saturday morning cartoon.

Said story is an interesting baggage as well, since it likes to switch narrative styles. Initially, it is a time-travel tale set in the apocalyptic future, as presented by the first protagonist, Fay, who went back to 1982 to convince a retired biologist, Bent, to continue his research into clean energy. This leads into a family drama between Bent and his son, which somehow turns into a James Bond movie against an evil energy mogul who hides in his private fortress in the jungle. And finally, the entire plot just ends in a very Shyamalan-like twist.

Gameplay is almost as varied as the storytelling: we start with relying on inventory-related puzzles in the future segments; dialogues, distraction, and some investigations in the initial chapters set in the present; and finally, old-school point ‘n’ click adventure insanity for the conclusion. This variance is refreshing to some degree, and it usually fits well within the current narrative, but it also feels like as if the game struggles to find its own identity and just experiments with whatever the creators just came up with. The result is an enjoyable, but probably too distracting product that can be recommended to adventure game fans only.

reviewText:
A New Beginning - Final Cut is a Point & Click adventure game. At the turn of the 26th century, mankind is about to be extinct as the last few hundred left won't survive the next solar flare. Sent back in time to prevent a climate catastrophy, Radio-operator Fay approaches Bent Svensson, a retired physicist, in hopes that his work an algae-based power source could save the world.

Pros: The story is interesting, having a slightly dark tone to it. You alternate between characters, viewing the story through their eyes, or through the way they tell their story. All cut-scenes are comicbook-styled boxes and text bubbles, while the gameplay scenes all appears hand-drawn in the most classical fashion of Point & Click games, topped with often dramatic tone-setting music. You must regularly interact with the environment and/or your inventory to solve puzzles, while standalone single-screen puzzles may be skipped after a few attempts, for those who want to.

Cons: The immersion is totally broken by the bad voice acting. The voices themselves would portray the characters fine for the most part while other times it's just silly, but the lack of any conviction in the way the dialog is so blatantly read directly off the script is what kills it. There are sync problems with the cutscenes, with reading pauses when the text changes line, sometimes even in mid sentence! There are a few translation glitches in some subtitles or interactions, and in a variety of languages, too (I saw some French and I believe some Russian, while playing the English version). The sprite animation is very frame-by-frame and not very smooth.

Verdict: ★★★☆☆ - It's up to you

I may have been harsh on the game's technical and audio flaws, but I nevertheless enjoyed my ride through the story. Sometimes optimistic, sometimes bitter, the game really made me wonder whether it would have a happy ending or not. In the end, I do recommend this game to anyone who wants to find out for themselves.

—————————————————————————
This was just my opinion.

If you found this review helpful, please consider giving it a thumbs up, and feel free to check out more of my (purely opinionated) reviews.

Very decent point&click adventure with a message and morale.

You control Fay, a woman from the future on a quest back in time to save the planet as its dying in her world, and the man she meets, Bent Svensson, a scientist, whom Fay believes can save the world.

The sound and music is decent there is definitely some flaws in the voice acting, particularly with main character Fay. Others also seem to 'overact'. Fays posture is also terrible, nobody can stand like that with a normally shaped spine.

Anyways; the rest of the game is decent, but you will probably need a guide at some of the puzzles. There is normally a reset button, on only one puzzles (water pumps) it's possible to ♥♥♥♥up so you need to reload. Note that the game does not autosave outside of remembering where you are, so you must save in order to get around this one puzzle if you want the achievement for playing all minigames. I also had Fay get stuck at one point, forcing be to reload from a save.

It also has some weird bugs; for example a rock/plank puzzle I was obviously supposed to walk over the plank, then  pick it up and put it towards the next rock, but when I clicked to pick up the plank, Fay would walk over to the rock I was on before, then pick it up. She did this three times before she finally decided to pick it up on the rock she was supposed to be on. Had it not been such an obvious solution I would have thought I did something wrong and backtracked/messed about other things for a long time. I assume the puzzle requires perfect positioning or something.
Also 2 times in the game were the 'use item' options in Russian and near the end at an important scene the subtitles is in German with no English voiceacting. Very annoying.

Some of the achievements are also mutually exclusive, so a save must be made before some puzzles/encounters to make life easier.

The story is about saving the world from environmental disaster, so yes, there is quite a lot of talk about saving the environment and all life is precious etc. It did not bother me much as it was part of the story.
The story is long, 12 hours+ without skipping anything and the ending was imo very interesting.

Recommended; but be aware of possible bugs, lacking voice acting, and environmental talks. Save often in many slots, and keep a guide at hand for the most complicated puzzles.

As a game, I really enjoyed the puzzle-solving aspect and the beautiful, hand-drawn backgrounds (though the character animation leaves a little to be desired - Fay's posture and walk are perplexing, to say the least). Like many good point-and-click adventure games, the puzzles involve thoroughly searching your surroundings to find needed objects, and then figuring out where and how to use them. Other times, making certain dialogue choices when interacting with other characters will lead you to your goals. I got stumped quite often - sometimes I'd just fumble into the right solution, and other times I'd work it out logically - but in the case of the latter, there were many times when I'd think I was on the right track, only to find I was still several steps away from the solution. reviewText:
Finding a new favorite band with a wide-ranging catalogue often presents the early works question. What to do and say about the things the band recorded before finding their own style and making a breakthrough? Listening to that may present new perspectives on their best work but is that reason enough to actually try and enjoy it on its own merits? This is the question I thought often during my hours with A New Beginning, one of the first titles from my recent favorite, Daedalic Entertainment.

Many key strengths presented later are already here, particularly those related to craftsmanship. The whole of the story is well laid out and plotted, with twists all in place and the whole progressing logically throughout with interesting puzzles challenging the brain. Another trademark is the orchestral soundtrack covering a wide range of moods and emotions. And finally comes of course the hand-made art showing once again that no tesselations can ever replace the human touch.

Making parts and assembling them is one thing but then breathing life into the result is another and this is where the game sadly does not succeed. The eco-conscious bent of the story is laudable but the tone is too educational and the contrasts are simply much too black-and-white. There was no room to disagree about anything or anyone or make alternative interpretations to what the writing told me. Consequently there was an airless quality to the entire experience. No characters had enough detail to give them life beyond caricatures with calculated positions in the story (and the message). Dialogue contained many odd phrases that smack of poor translation. A grim security officer shuts off doubt with Fiddlesticks!" and in more than one life-threatening situation "Good grief" gets used too.

I'll be honest, I struggled with whether or not to recommend A New Beginning.  On the one hand, it has an ambitious story, a classic look and feel, pleasant music, puzzles which are challenging without being too terribly difficult (in most cases).  On the other hand, some of the puzzles were quite cryptic, and there are some bugs.  I saw a number of times where the popup choices on an item would suddenly show up in Russian; a few times where clicking on hotspots was simply ignored and I had to close out of the game through Task Manager and load an earlier save; a few times where dialog interactions would go by at the speed of light, important information was missed and I had to load an earlier save; once where I had clicked on an item to interact while the character was moving to use a dialog tree, the mouse was snapped to the item interaction but the game was waiting for dialog interaction--again, had to quit through Task Manager and reload.

That said, despite the bugs, despite the stilted voice acting, despite small and easily-missed hotspots that are required to proceed and can make you wander around for half an hour at a time, there is a well-crafted story in this game.  Just be prepared to overlook a lot of flaws to find it.  Of course, if you're a fan of the point-and-click adventure format, you're probably used to doing that.

Final verdict: Worthwhile, but wait for at least 50% off.

Or as the game would have it... reversible through time travel. The puzzles aren't very hard and they are even skippable if you can't figure them out in a few minutes. The game isn't very long, about 5-6 hours, which is both a strength, because it doesn't waste time with irrelevant details and makes the story more concentrated, and a weakness, because who doesn't want more of a good thing?\n\nOverall it's a very enjoyable experience, my only tips would be a) change spoken language to German because the voice acting in English is terrible to say the least (you can do this from the panel with little bubbles that contain flags, in the main menu as you start the game), it's very robotic - you can keep subtitles in English so you understand what's being said though; b) don't try to rush actions as the game can bug out, you can also speed things up by double-clicking the areas where the cursor changes into arrows for fast-loading (so you don't have to wait for animations to finish each time).

reviewText:
Summary:  An average point-and-click adventure game with a stupid story, a poorly written ending and a badly conveyed environmental message. But decent puzzle design. Buy it cheap, try to ignore the story and you’ll have a decent time with it.

Full review:  You play as Bent Svensson, a retired and miserable algae researcher, and Fay, a time-travelling radio operator sent from the future to save humanity from global warming. She will do so by getting people to use Svensson’s algae to produce energy instead of fossil fuels and atomic power. As characters they are… okay. You can have a lot of comments about Fay, but at least she is not Goal from Deponia, who spends the entire game unconscious and is nothing but the “Goal” for the male protagonist. Fay’s not particularly funny, but she’s okay to play as. Same with Bent, not the most uplifting character, but decently portrayed. This can be contrasted with some of the side-characters that are just god-awful. Especially Duve, Bent’s son, who I would say is probably one of the worst designed characters I’ve even seen. The voice-acting also ranges from decent to pretty bad, though I often got the feeling it was not the voice-actors fault but rather how they recorded and handled the audio files.

The story is pretty stupid. Time-travel tends to bring that out in a story, but unfortunately it is not limited to just the time-travel. I appreciate the message they are trying to convey, I really do. Unfortunately it is told in such a heavy-handed manner and in such simplistic terms that it loses all meaning and is very unlikely to convince anyone. After a while they try to go a little deeper into the issues, but it is too little too late.  Other than that, the story is functional if uninteresting throughout most of the game… until the finale, which just utterly sucks. For the sake of a “twist” they completely disregard everything that has happened previously and what little rationale they had for their characters suddenly vanish. I mean, if the ending is true, why is Bent even in the game at all? Incredibly poorly written.

The puzzles then. They are the standard Deadalic mix of item-based puzzles with some minigames thrown in to add variety. Overall I found the puzzle design pretty good and really the only reason to play the game. Just like other games of the genre there were some instances of puzzles not making that much sense, but these instances were comparatively few. On the other hand, there are also no real head-scratchers or anything particularly inventive about the puzzles either. Pretty bog-standard.

So, why am I even recommending this game? Because the puzzles are pretty nice. And even though the story is not very good, it was not until the very end that it’s really awful. It’s an average title that you should buy cheap and play for the puzzles. Or get a really good adventure game instead.

So my quest to play all and review my games library finally got to A. Unfortunately my magpie sense tingled and I recently purchased another bundle which has set me back onto the numbers. Also steam recently reclassified this game into N which I suppose makes sense but its irked me a bit. Mind that is a issue I need to take with steam and not this game.

So this is a point and click 2d game, and a pretty competent one at that. You play as one of two characters that you change between during the story, Bent, an Eco scientist, and Fay who is a time traveler from a despotic future ruined by climate change. They are trying to create a green fuel and make it the primary power source for the world as to prevent the future. I ended up enjoying the characters I was playing as. They both seem to have well thought out personalities, there isn't tonnes of back story for them though, and they do focus a lot on the environment. I have a friend who has played this game who says that they found it very preachy and there is a little bit of that, but it is to be expected. They both have dedicated their lives to this working out after all.

The game has 2 main sections, one is your traditional 2d point and clicking, inventory puzzles and dialogue trees etc. the second is a single screen puzzle that you have to solve.
A big problem I have seen with modern point and click games is that the difficulty level is much reduced. This is to encompass the casual tablet crowd as the lowest common denominator reaches the biggest market, and as a nerdy amiga/dosbox owning girl, I like my old school point and clicks. This game has a really nice feature which is rather than making all the interactive items stand out it keeps them plain in the background, however, holding down space will light them up. Also in the single screen puzzles which can take a while to figure out there is a skip button. I didn't use space or skip any of the puzzles but it is nice to see that they are optional. I do find the skip button a bit annoying as I feel that if you can't beat a game then you need to suck it up rather than whining to the developers to make it easier and easier however I do prefer it to them simplifying it even more. Modern point and click can be very bittersweet but this one is much more sweet than some of the rubbish on my friend's ipad.

There is one place that this game seriously falls down though, and thats in the Quality Assurance. I understand that English is not the first language of the developers, and I do want to take it easy on them, but it is a taint that makes what would be an adept example of the genre unfortunately adequate. It's a shame too, because a thorough testing session should have picked these up and it comes off feeling a bit lazy and sloppy, but the rest of the game wasn't. I really do feel for the developers and I hope that people don't criticise them too hard for this.
The game has numerous spelling errors but as I say, not a first language. However often the dialogue on the screen and the vocal speech are different and using completely different, albeit similar words. I found that the on screen text tended to be a bit more detailed than the dialogue so I treated that as canon. There was also an instance where a character was saying dialogue choice one when he should have been saying choice two. There are a few parts in the game where you can click to move your character into a spot where they shouldn't go, and they wander off getting smaller and smaller until they are but a pixel. Again, this is not the fault of the programmers. Character scaling while walking off into the distance is a good thing, these are boundaries that QA should be pointing out. Another time I got stuck in a bar, I could not get him out no matter how hard I tried, luckily an exit was just in view and I could double click to fast travel him out. Late in chapter 6 clicking on an inventory item was giving me dialogue all the way back from chapter 2. I'm sure if I was willing to give it a second play through I could find more bugs now that I know some of the triggers.
It is a shame it is so buggy but please don't let that put you off. If you like the genre there is nothing wrong with this game at all, just maybe think about waiting for a sale.
I have other games from these guys, really looking forward to getting round to them!

Over all, I recommend the game if you enjoy adventure games with an interesting message and a good amount of attention paid to deatil.

reviewText:
A New Beginning is a wonderfully crafted Point & Click adventure from Daedelic which weaves an intricate story around real world issues, namely climate change. The story is well paced and surprisingly enjoyable considering the premise and along with the subtle humour it results in a fun time which is arguably well spent. To help retain your attention the game jumps between contrasting environments and relies on a small cast of main characters to carry the story towards it's conclusion all the while fleshing out those individuals and subtly explaining how the events affect them on a personal level.

You play as both Bent Svenson and a mysterous woman called Faye who become involved in a plot that promises to change the world as we know it and then some. Both characters bring something fresh and new to the table, where Bent isn't exactly a spring chicken, he does have a sharp mind and deep pockets. His limitations are often covered by Faye as she goes to great lengths to achieve her goal but is limited by her naivety and her smaller pockets. The people they come into contact with are usually affected in some form or another in order to fully immerse the player in each sequence of events and make them think that their actions matter.

The voice acting for the main characters is very good as it helps to make them relatable and makes the events that transpire all the more harrowing when it directly involves them. Other characters such as Duve (pronounced Du-va) and Oggy show significant character progression over the course of the game which ultimately makes them likable people despite their inital negative impression and that is primarily down to their voice actors doing such a temendous job.

Point & Clicks are not known for their innovation so don't expect Batman: Arkham Asylum-style controls, but as this genre goes, A New Beginning does try to initivate where it can. A simple right click will bring up the inventory to use items, which is useful as it does not obstruct 10% of the scenery but the fact that it will not appear if the cursor is hovered over where it is makes the process needlessly elongated. In a game where many items are used on many things this small problem does become irritating. Other negatives include the subtitles occasionally not matching up with the dialogue from the characters which again is a small problem, but the fact it happens numerous times, does make it notable. The story also seems to tie up certain plot points rather abruptly or unsatisfactorily towards the middle of the game which leave the player confused and the wonderful music that often accompanies big moments is often missing through the majority of the game.

Overall though A New Beginning is an incredibly fascinating piece that takes a controversial topic and makes it into art. That alone is worth praise in a market where Dev's just love to copy the concepts of War, Religion and violence from each other in order to make money. The fact that the plot is interesting, the characters are memorable and the in-game atmosphere is tense makes A New Beginning a good place to start for young gamers looking to get into the medium and old school adventurers who crave mind-bending puzzles and a thrilling story.

reviewText:
A new beginnig indeed.

This game is a point and click game by Daedalic.

I love point and click games, and I love the storytellers Daedalic, so it is no surprise I give this game a thumps up, but I will still talk about the game and it`s strong and weak sides.

The games story is about Ben who had to give up his project of making algae fuel, then he is visited by a girl named Fey, who claims to be from the futher.

Ben is skeptic about her story, but when she reveials that a nuclear powerplant will blow up in the future,and therefore make the earth uninhabitable Ben changes he`s mind, and start to work together with the girl.

Now at the same time, the son of Ben is trying to sell the algae project, to the person who owns the powerplant. He has of couse no intention of using the algae for fuel, but will insteed destroy the algae, so that nuclear power looks to be the only good way to stop pollution.

Ben and Fey are both great charecters, and they show a lot of potentiol in the game, I have a problem with the voiceacting thoe.

Normally I can accept that voiceactors can be hard to come by, and don`t missunderstand me, it`s one of the hardest forms of acting, but in a point and click game, the voices and personas of the charecters in the game is so important, becouse the gameplay part is not a new invention or anything. The gameplay is a bit slow as you would expect, becouse it`s a point and click game. It is driven by the story, and this games story is great to follow, and some of the twists in the story is really well thought out.

Eventhough there is some bad voiceacting here and there (looking at you Fey) the story is great, and the overall experience is very good for a point and click game.

One minor thing to end on. I have troubles understanding why you can skip puzzels in the game. Now and again there will be puzzels in the game, and they are at times easy and other times hard. So why did they inclued a skip button? I mean don`t remove all the gameplay, let people think things out (or look it up, I know the gaming comunity to well by now).

Well thats it, an ordinary pont and click game with a greaat story to share 6 out of 10

reviewText:
I began this game cynical it was going to be full of milk bottle recycling, kitten saving and tacky eco guilt. However, I ended up being gripped by a very serious plot with good momentum and beautiful art. Thankfully, moral ambiguity is a bigger theme than the eco stuff.

The strongest point of A New Beginning is its puzzles. They're the perfect difficulty to pose a challenge while not stalling the pace. They're logical, well designed and fun.

The games weaknesses are a few technical and translation glitches, the characters aren't particularly likeable, and a few things don't make sense, including the ending. The game as a whole feels a little unfinished, like they were definitely on track to making a perfect game but then got forced to release it in its current state.

However, I was pleasantly surprised with this game and enjoyed it. At the price, it's a must have for adventure game fans. I will be checking out the other games from Daedalic after discovering this.

reviewText:
In A New Beginning, your mission is to save the world from the effects of climate change. It is a standard point and click adventure game. This game can suffer from a bit of the old adventure game crazy logic.  Nothing too crazy, but some of the solutions are a little out there. The story picks up and gets interesting in the middle acts, but really falters quite a bit toward the end. Also, their message about climate change is hammered home over and over again.

I can't tell if it's just a problem with my computer, but it seems to be stuck in fullscreen mode with a low resolution. This must be an iOS port, which I didn't know ahead of time. That's not a deal breaker, but it could look better. The environments and characters are all drawn well. The cutscenes are all done in a graphic novel style which looks great. The voice acting can be a little jarring at times and leave a bit to be desired. The overall sound effects and music are enjoyable.

This won't change your mind about point and click adventures if you aren't a fan of the genre,  but if you like them alread it's worth the time.

Grade: C+

reviewText:
I have to admit from the start: I am an adventure fanatic. I love point and click games and the adventure genre is probably the only one that can immerse me fully in the story, it feels at times like I am directing my own movie based on a very strict script. I have been playing a few titles from Daedalic lately and find them all to be pretty good, especially on the artwork side of things.

A New Beginning is simply put: gorgeous! The sceneries are beautifully drawn and the comic book style cutscenes are beautiful, engaging and quite unique, I haven't seen them done in any other game so far. The only issue with the graphics side of things that I can find is the actual characters. They feel extremely out of place in some of the scenes, they difference in detail is quite striking at times and their placement in the scene looks off from time to time. A little more attention to animation and placement would have been nice to see. The interface is minimalistic and easy to access, there's no extra buttons to be pressed, a right click on the mouse and you can easily toggle the inventory.

The soundtrack is also great, the composed songs really fit the game and its circumstances so it also scores high points for sound design. The only issue that I can find with this game is voice acting. Seriously, this could have been a perfect game if not for the lousy voice acting. It really sounds like the actors read line after line without putting them into context, more like a monologue than a dialogue which sounds extremely silly at times and quite unprofessional. And speaking of lines, the script is quite poorly written. You get the feeling that the characters are either uneducated or plain ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. Don't get me wrong, I don't expect people in a game to speak like a Literature PhD, but definitely not like someone who barely finished high school.

Speaking of the script I should also address the story. It's a little cliche if you ask me, the kind of story that reminds you of those 90's television-made movies that try to blend action with drama, but also convey a strong message and meaning while not bothering the viewer with questions and instead putting any answers straight on the table. A New Beginning also tries to send a message but it does poorly and scarcely and only focuses on this aspect by the end of the game. It also tries to do it via the aforementioned poor voice acting leaving you rather facepalmed and laughing out loud that deeply moved and touched. It does, however, make up for it in the final scene, which unfortunately appears right at the end of the credits which can be skipped so most of the players will definitely miss this one.

All in all this was a great game to play with an immersive story, great sound design and loads of puzzles ranging from moderate to hard and many actions that require out-of-the box thinking so it can be both challenging and frustrating at times. The game also has a seamless auto-save feature so if your game happens to crash just hit continue on the main screen (the autosave is not visible in the load menu).

I give this one a 8.5/10

reviewText:
Time traveling hippies are trying to save the world by begging a grumpy norwegian scientist to help them. The story really isn't too interesting, it's the kinda ”I started reading it, now I have to see it through until the end, as it would bother me not to know.” It's pretty predictable with a standard cheesy bad guy involved.

As for the characters, there really wasn't anyone I particularly liked or stood out to me. Fay could have been a very interesting character by telling of her time and how she grew up, but you only get a few ideas of how her world is like. Appearently she is supposed to be so clueless about the world as she doesn't even know what coffee is, yet she knows how to use a fax. She seems to swap knowledge throughout the story. The main character Bent is unlikable. Grumpy man who can't admit being wrong and doesn't really try either even though the plot gives him several oppertunities to make things right between himself and his family.
I do give the game credit for featuring a gay character.

The game is extremely buggy and utterly clumsy at times. The main problem being the cursor and how you interact with things. To interact with something, you have to leftclick and hold, then steer the mouse towards the option you want and then let go. Many times I found myself struggling to select the choice I wanted. The control feels extremely unresponsive at times. Sometimes it's also hard to interact with the objects on the screen. I had to look at a guide on the internet to advance at one point, because I really couldn't make the cursor register a pair of keys unless I knew exactly in what area to click. Other times I followed a guide and I still had problems activating certain items. The game can be annoyingly picky at times. Certain times you need to open every drawer, other times you only need to click on one drawer to open them all. Due to being forced into this awkward click-hold-and-steer combination, I often find myself being unable to deselect items without having the character comment on it. Sometimes the dialogue can be quite long, so missclicks becomes tedious.

Secondly, the game wasn't obviously throughouly tested. One part of the game, the dialogue skipped completely and the objects I interacted with were so unresponsive, that I missed the whole dialogue in one of the important scenes. And it wasn't just some random talk, it was a key plot event.
Sometimes certain objects wouldn't trigger any reactions at all, making me wonder if I failed to click it. Other times, it caused the character to suddenly speak german! There are options in the games that are not translated at all. One door only has two russian options, neither which I could understand what they meant.
The end credits are bugged, you only get to see half before the game skips and loads something else.
The subtitles in the game don't always match up with what the characters say and sometimes the text loads long before the dialogue is even spoken.

The voiceacting in the game was horrible! Almost every actor in the game has a wooden, monotone speech. No matter the situation, they have the same level of emotion. During critical situations or emotionally charged scenes, you really notice how terrible it is. It's obvious at times the actors aren't even trying. The main characters are unfortunately among the worst actors.

I don't know whether it was a fault of the translation or because I just couldn't follow the plot, but more than half the time I had no idea what the characters wanted me to do. The characters don't give any good clues when you use objects, just some random nonsense like ”No”, ”Um”, ”Nope”, ”Hm”, ”Nah”. I don't feel like I have had this problem before with these kinds of games, usually you are provided with a clear objective. There are also times where I was quite baffled as the game seemed to skip out on it's own plot and advanced anyway. As an example, Fay decides to go looking for a person, but then she just... forgets about it? And that's even after making a huge deal about finding the person.

It's unfortunate the game is riddled with so many bad things, because the artwork and style is amazing. I loved how the game plays out like a comic and the characters look drawn in every environment, blending in perfectly with the background. Visually, this game is so pleasing to the eyes. The way the comic styled art is drawn during the ”cutscenes” is interesting to watch and feels very unique. The whole game feels like reading a comic book rather than just playing a PC game.
Unfortunately, the horrendous voiceacting manages to ruin it. You see Bent or Fay expressing a strong emotion, but the only thing you hear is the emotional investment of a decaying zombie.

This was my first Daedalic Entertainment game, and I was not disappointed.

This game has a deep story, which kept me intrigued throughout the game. The story gives out a strong message about global warming and the effects it had on the world in the future. Such a heart warming story. At no point was I bored or lost with what I had to do next. The puzzles were well thought out, and always kept you thinking.

The best part of the game has to be the art style, with a nice graphic novel theme going on. Very fitting for all the areas in the game, be it the past and future parts.

The characters were ace, I loved each and every one of them with their characteristics and involvement in the story. Even with the minor characters, which you saw / interacted with briefly.

There are a few minor bugs with the game, the ones I noticed were the translations being shown in game. At a couple points, my sub titles and hovering over items would switch to Russian text. But the game remained English audio. That was the main issue I had with the game, but it usually picked its self up again after leaving and re-entering a screen.

In conclusion:
The game has a strong, point hitting story.
It uses stunning novel graphics, which are very well drawn.
Fantastic and brain boggling puzzles to solve.
Rememberable characters.
Beautiful cinematic cut scenes, played out in a comic strip style.
There are some visual translation bugs, where it does switch to another language time to time.
8 / 10, well worth playing at least once.

reviewText:
This has got to be one of the worst point & click I've ever played. Apart from the base artwork (not including the average comic cutscenes), the whole thing feels really amateurish. The gameplay is ridiculously messy and tedious (for example, why do we have to hold the mouse button for every single interaction, why?? and why are some elements in big puzzles so hard to click?), which is quite mind-boggling for a point & click game. Add some terrible puzzle designs to this and you get a pretty unpleasant game to play overall. Hell, you just need to go 5 minutes into the game to feel something is wrong thanks to this crazy non-sensical 1st puzzle. For this reason, I ended up using a walkthrough to get through after a few hours in, because I still wanted to know where the story was going.

Speaking of the story, it feels like it's been written by some naive 14 years old who just got into environmental activism. The poor translation and dreadful acting probably doesn't help, but it still feels incredibly cheesy and convoluted, especially near the end. In fact, it felt like watching a really bad 80s movie where everything gets so ridiculous it becomes funny and that's probably what kept me playing till the end! For this reason alone, I'd recommend this game, if the gameplay wasn't so painful.

Anyway, if you like point & click games, don't let this deter you from other Daedelic titles. They're usually quite successful at crafting very nice characters and universes. I especially enjoyed the Edna & Harvey and the Deponia series for instance.

AVOID AT ALL COST !!!

I'm sorry, but I cannot recommend the normal user to buy this sh*t.

Want to know why? Well, read on ...

This game here features unexpected crashes, sound stopping to work at all, overall laggyness out of nowhere and no stretching on 16:9 / 16:10 monitors.

The funny thing is, when you finally got the sound working the levels for the different type of sounds are totally nuts. There really is no better way to describe this. You have to fiddle around endlessly with the in game configuration to somehow get it all working together in a way you could finally sort of enjoy this game and when this hassle is done you're blown away from the next cutscene because the levels in these are crazy loud compared to the rest of the game.

WTF ?!? ... I mean really ... WTF ?!? ... I am no professional sound-editor but I know how to join different sources together so they sound fine alltogether (and nearly every other game producing company seems to know too), but the thing is, that is not my work but the work of Daedalic. The levels are so far out, sorry, but everyone in production should have easily mentioned this.

At least the voice overs in this game are finally sort of enjoyable. In most older games from this company they just did sound ridiculous. So this is a plus for this game here. The graphics viewes as stills look nice to, because they feature nicely handdrawn backgrounds with wisely chosen colour palettes but the animation is horrible. In some way it's better than in other games from Daedalic (like the whispered world for eg.) but in now way are they appealing to look at.

The story sound interesting too, but until now I couldn't really investigate it because the game won't let me to, at least not with sound. I mean, after every restart of the game the sound is gone. And I haven't got a clue why.

Well ... after all ... As said before this game has many issues:

- Sound not working or working bad,
- Laggy gameplay,
- Devs that won't answer in these forums here only by email (guess why),
- Configuration spread over ingame and out-of- game configuration tools,
- Horrbile startup loading time
- No Background music in the menus
- Cutoff Background music in the credits and the intro
- No widescreen support (devs don't like it though gamers ask them all over the internet *lol*),
- Game-breaking save-game failures
- And not reproducable crashes of the whole game at random times.

And those mentioned before are just the errors that I did encounter personally while trying it ot for 2 hours (actually playing just maybe about 1 hour, the rest was problem solving and waiting for the game to load). But there are a lot more mentioned here and over the internet wich include:

- No sound during Cutscenes
- Wrong language in Cutscenes
- Game reproducable crashing as soon as a cutscene appears

Because of all the flaws I can only hardly recommend this game for lovers of the genre, as long as you can get it to work properly on your setup, but I would never buy it for the normal price. I got mine in a bundle so I think it's ok. But don't pay more for this game than 1,99 €.

And remember to avoid all other games from Daedalic unless they finally get these things addressed, because after searching the internet a little I found out that even in other (newer) games from Daedalic there are many people experiencing exactly the same problems, what leads me to think, that the problem lays in the engine underneath the games. What again is leading me to the question why these bugs aren't finally addressed so presumably a nice and simple fix for every game of the company could be released without much problems.

Maybe instead of releasing one mediocre made game after the other Daedalic should start releasing fewer but well made games so they could honestly ask real money for it? They have damned so many good ideas and concepts in the past it just makes me sad, because back in the days I loved adventure games so much and Daedalic is one of the few companies still (trying to) making them today ...

So the overhelming question is:

Will Daedalic ever produce a fully working adventure title? Sadly chances are very low. I can only hope they don't ♥♥♥♥ up the Blackguards series ...

reviewText:
DISCLAIMER: This is a repost from my blog at www.stanislavcostiuc.com. I don't write reviews. I write opinion and impressions pieces, meaning the detalization may vary from just general feelings about a game to indepth critique of particular game mechanics. Read if you're interested to know if I like a game or not (and for what reasons), which parts intrigue me and which parts push me away, but don't expect in-depth description of all gameplay and systems. Thank you.

I am a fan of classic point & click adventure games. And as a fan of adventure games, I want to really like A New Beginning, but I can’t. Which is sad, because the story really intrigues me, but there’s just too many flaws that accumulate and are hard to look past by in a title of this genre.

The interface is very laggy. To interact with objects, you hold the mouse button, a wheel appears, and you select the action from that wheel by moving the mouse around and then releasing it. In theory that’s a nice system, but in practice the way it’s implemented in A New Beginning is very annoying. It takes like half a second to a second for the game to realize that you’re holding the mouse, and then there’s a half a second to a second animation of the wheel appearing. And this really messes with the game flow. You interact with a lot of objects in an adventure game, and check what contextual actions are available, so in a minute of gameplay approximately 15 seconds are just waiting for the wheel to appear.

And speaking of actions, the wheel doesn’t have a set amount of them, it depends on the object itself. Which is why it’s so annoying when there’s a ‘Take’ action on an object which exists for the character to say that he doesn’t need it (the fact that you’ve spent a whole second or two initiating the action doesn’t help). And you get this feeling that maybe in the future you’ll have to backtrack to take this object and you’re gonna be angry on the character for not taking it in the first place (I actually can’t confirm this, since after the location with this example we go to a flashback of the second main character, but if we won’t ever have to use a fishing rod and a fishing net in the game, I’ll be angry). And you know, an argument can be applied that it was an attempt to remove the ‘adventure game logic’, when you take everything with you and possibly solve puzzles before they appear, but considering that in a later section I’ve recharged a battery before knowing why I need it, I’m not sure that applies (also I still don’t know what certain objects in my inventory in later part of the game are for, I took them just because).

When it comes to ‘adventure game logic’, I think that gameplay flow should be a bigger priority than having everything make perfect chronological sense. Speaking of sense, there was a moment in the prologue when I needed to ask a second character for help. I had to ask her to hold a shutter so nothing would fall out from the fogger. But I couldn’t. I knew I had to ask her because as I failed to close the shutter and looked at it, my character said that he needs a second person to hold it before turning the fogger on, but the actual topic of the conversation with said person doesn’t appear until I actually try turning the fogger on (which leads to the exact same thought line, by the way). These kind of specific things in an adventure game are very detrimental to the experience.

Adventure games are usually very story heavy. And dialogue heavy. And most of them are quite linear. This problem is usually tackled in two ways. In adventure games with linear dialogue (without ability to choose topics), conversations are usually relatively short and to the point, so you can continue exploring and figuring things out rather quickly. And in adventure with non-linear dialogue, there’s, well, there’s all the topics to choose from, and you don’t have to go through them all, you might want to just select only the important ones if you feel like it (so even though overall you’re more passive in an adventure game, you’re still active). But there was only just one (and a half-ish) non-linear conversation during the parts that I’ve played. Everything else was just comic-style cutscenes which also really slowed down the pace – you had to wait for the panels to appear in a cool way before a line was spoken. Each panel animation is not too long in and on its own, but, again, it adds up. So A New Beginning felt more like watching a visual novel rather than playing an adventure game. And even then, the conversations are slow due to a considerable delay between each line.

And there’s also the fact that English voice acting is so monotone and boring that I would recommend to just switch to the original German (or maybe other translation that is actually good) immediately.

But what A New Beginning has really got going for it is the beautiful art style (although, admittedly, the quality of animations may vary from action to action) and a story that has managed to intrigue me, and I want to know how it all turns out in the end. This may seem like a very short point, but it’s actually huge, and plays a lot to the game’s favor. It will have to wait though, until I don’t really have anything else to play. Sadly, I don’t think A New Beginning is well designed as a point & click adventure game. There’s too much passivity, and gameplay doesn’t flow well at all. Maybe I’m missing out. Maybe further down the road things get better. And if they do, I’ll make another post. But as it stands, this particular adventure game wouldn’t be on the top of my recommend list.

reviewText:
This is a game that is flat out average. Gameplay is a-typical point and click, the interface is poor, the voice acting is atrocious (in English) and there are plenty of translation errors and issues as well as a few bugs that are blindingly obvious and haven't been fixed.

But I give it a thumbs up for any adventure fan who likes a decent tale, and I would give it a 'maybe'; if we had that option.

A New Beginning tackles time-travel and all the tropes related to it, alongside Climate Change and Environmentalism. It sounds preachy and the message is rather banal and simple all the way until the very end of the game. There, the plot twist contains the true message of the game, one that is honest and brutal.

Is the game worth buying just for that message? Probably not, it certainly won't amuse anyone who hates climate activism, it isn't going to be a glorious cup of tea for anyone outside of adventure / point and click hardcore nuts, but I think the message it holds is a rather reasonable and interesting one to listen to. Buy it on extreme discounts (It was a low as 0.50 when I paid for it), but don't pay full price as the game simply isn't refined enough.
